title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1897

entries.fullText:
Meir Maggie [Mr. S. Dobson?]
1590 - Eights St. - San Diego - Cal -

24
The Penn United Life Insurance Company - 921-928 - Chestnut St., Philadelphia, Pa.
entries.summaryText: Meir Maggie and possibly Mr. S. Dobson? are in San Diego on Eights St. and there is a mention of The Penn United Life Insurance Company in Philadelphia.

entries.fullText: [Sister Mary & self at home alone - Julia at her home Churchville--] Visited Mrs Miller - Geneva - to be with Hattie Stanton & her daughter Nora $300
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Mrs. Miller in Geneva with Sister Mary and was accompanied by Hattie Stanton and her daughter Nora. She also mentions Julia being at her home in Churchville. She notes a financial transaction of $300.

entries.fullText: At Home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from January 2, 1897, written at home.

entries.fullText:
Unitarian Church
W.C. Gannett
In evening went
to Mr & Mrs Charles
W. Fitch's--Mrs Craig
came in--close
talk on woman
question
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from January 3, 1897, written at the Unitarian Church and later at Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Fitch's home. W.C. Gannett and Mrs. Craig were mentioned, and there was a close talk on the woman question.

entries.fullText: At Home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home on January 4th, 1897.

entries.fullText:
Took 7:20 R. & P. for
Castile - Wyoming Conf -
to visit Frances
Willard - who with
her Anna Gordon - two
sisters & mother - have
a home there with Miss
Daily - & Miss W. takes
treatment at the
sanitarium of Dr
Cordelia Green -
and we talked over
& over every question
& everybody - Lady
Henry Somerset -
- Dr Green come over to
tea & spent evening -
entries.summaryText: On January 5th, 1897, Susan B. Anthony traveled to Castile in Wyoming Conf to visit Frances Willard and her family. They discussed various topics and were joined by Lady Henry Somerset and Dr. Cordelia Green for tea in the evening.

entries.fullText:
all of us went over
to the Doctors to
dinner - after it - I
talked to the patients
in the parlors - & at
3.20 took stage for
train & reached
Rochester at 6.20 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the Doctors for dinner and talked to patients in the parlors before taking a stage for train and reaching Rochester at 6.20 P.M.
Susan B. Anthony was at home.

entries.fullText: Went to U. Church
entries.summaryText: Attended U. Church.

entries.fullText:
Telegram from Caroline E.
Merrick - New Orleans - La -
saying Judge Merrick died
this morning - he was 30 years
old than she - so must have
been near 90
entries.summaryText: Caroline E. Merrick sends a telegram from New Orleans, LA, announcing the death of Judge Merrick who was around 90 years old.

entries.fullText:
at home
with Mrs Sweet
at work all this
week -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with Mrs. Sweet and works all week.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs. Maud Humphrey
of Warsaw- spent
night with us - she
in city attending the
Ex. Com. meeting of
Federated Clubs
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Maud Humphrey from Warsaw spent the night with Susan B. Anthony who was at home. Mrs. Humphrey was in the city attending the Ex. Com. meeting of Federated Clubs.

entries.fullText:
Luncheon - of
Federated Clubs Ex. Com.
given by Educational &
Industrial Union etc - at
Genessee Club house -
Mrs Helen Barrett Montgomery
Pres - nice company of
ladies - after it
went to Plymouth
Church--Ethical Club
meeting - Mrs Danforth Jr -
Pres - subject insanity -
Dr [Prallanyne?] - Sister
Mary went R. R. Station &
brought Charlotte Perkins
Stetson - who was introduced to
to the 800 or 1000 women &
recited a poem--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a luncheon of Federated Clubs Ex. Com. given by Educational & Industrial Union at Genessee Club house. She then went to Plymouth Church for an Ethical Club meeting where Dr [Prallanyne?] spoke on the subject of insanity. Sister Mary brought Charlotte Perkins Stetson to the meeting, who recited a poem to the 800 or 1000 women present.

entries.fullText:
This evening a goodly
number of friends
called to meet Mrs
Stetson - Mrs
Sanford & sister Mrs
Perry here to tea
entries.summaryText: A gathering of friends including Mrs Stetson, Mrs Sanford, and Mrs Perry took place.

entries.fullText:
All - Sister Mary
Mrs Stetson & self
went to U. Church
heard Rev
Eastman - of Elmira -
associate Pastor with
his wife - with Rev
Thomas K. Beecher -
Mr Gannett gone to
Elmira -
The evening Mrs Stetson
spoke in Church on
"Collective Ethics" - to a
full house - & a
good col - $16 result
entries.summaryText: Attended church and heard Rev Eastman and Rev Thomas K. Beecher. Mrs Stetson spoke on 'Collective Ethics' in the evening to a full house and raised $16.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary, Mrs Stetson & self Lunched with Mrs. Gannett - Mr G. had returned & Mr Eastman remained over - so we had a long & full talk on individual & collective conscience -- It is a great question - Word comes that Mrs Murphy of N. Jersey left us a $500+ bequest
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary, Mrs Stetson, and Susan B. Anthony had lunch with Mrs. Gannett and discussed individual and collective conscience. They also received news of a $500 bequest from Mrs. Murphy of New Jersey.

entries.fullText: We all lunched with Mrs & Dr Sanford - to meet Mrs Simpson Hahers - - a lecturer on art. - Mrs Lozier of Batavia there -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and others had lunch with Mrs. and Dr. Sanford to meet Mrs. Simpson Hahers, a lecturer on art. Mrs. Lozier of Batavia was also present.

entries.fullText: Took 10.37. Mich. Central train - with Ms. Charlotte Perkins Stetson - for Chicago - had a hard day packing & getting ready to leave home. Sister Mary & Mrs Stetson went to Y.M.C.A. Hall to hear Ms Helen Barrett Montgomery on current topics - & Mrs G. invited Mrs S. to recite a poem
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Chicago with Ms. Charlotte Perkins Stetson and attends a lecture by Ms. Helen Barrett Montgomery.

entries.fullText: Reached Chicago at 2.50 P.M. Dear Ms Gross met us - Mrs S. went to her friends - & I with Mrs. G. - & there in my lovely tapestried room was the new Louis the 14th $5,200 - bed - stead and bureau for me to christen!! My! how much good suffrage work could have been done for that money - Mrs. Armstrong - Ed. of the Chicago Society paper - The Elite - there to dinner & remained until 12 Oclock - Oh I was sleepy!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Chicago and stays in a luxurious room, while reflecting on the cost of the furniture. She has dinner with Mrs. Armstrong, the editor of The Elite.

entries.fullText: Spent all the day at Mrs Gross - until evening then went over to Mrs. Coonleys to a social -some 20 - to hear Mrs. Stetson Mrs Frank Sanborn of Concord there also Mrs. Ruth McEvery Stuart- of Louisiana - now here - a writer & reciter of Southern Dialect stories
entries.summaryText: Attended a social event at Mrs. Coonleys and heard Mrs. Stetson, Mrs Frank Sanborn, and Mrs. Ruth McEvery Stuart recite Southern Dialect stories.

people: cousin Hannah Dickinson Doyle's daughter Kate
entries.fullText: Chicago - Ill Woman's Club 15 - Washington Street at 3. P.M - Mrs Gross - on way to club took me to Mandells & purchased a warm handsome jacket - 14.75 - - So I should not freeze - Miss Shaw soon appeared - & after my speech to the club she spoke beautifully - cousin Hannah Dickinson Doyle's daughter Kate + cousin Hannah Anthony daughter Maude there Miss Shaw dined at Mrs Grosses & at 4.20 Mrs. G took us to the R. R. Station - Wells st
entries.summaryText: Attended the Woman's Club in Chicago and purchased a jacket. Gave a speech and heard Miss Shaw speak beautifully. Had dinner at Mrs Grosses and went to the R. R. Station.

entries.fullText:
-- Rachel
& Nicolas landed in
Des Moines - Iowa
-- All drove to the
home of James &
Martha C Callahan --
Where we found Mrs Catt
& Miss Hay -- Mrs Upton & her
secretary -- & niece Lucy C. -- Alice
Blackwell not there -- but
we held business meeting --
I slept on a new iron
white & gold - bed stead down
stairs in library & at right
hand side of Hall -- The
mercury at 16 below zero!!
But all were made warm
& comfortable in that great mansion
entries.summaryText: Meeting with Miss Shaw, Rachel, Nicolas, Mrs Catt, Miss Hay, Mrs Upton, Lucy C., and Alice Blackwell in Des Moines, Iowa. Business meeting held and slept in a new bed.

entries.fullText:
Des Moines -- Iowa
Martha C. Callanan's
business meeting --
Alice Blackwell came
this day -- so all were
present -- Jane dear Mrs
S. B. Cooper who went over
the big river on Dec. 11. 1896!!
The Executive Com -
of the National met in
Mrs. C's parlor this
evening -- all came
almost frozen -- Sister
Mary arrived this A.M.
stopped at Mr Hatton's --
entries.summaryText: Business meeting with Martha C. Callanan and Alice Blackwell in Des Moines, Iowa. Executive Committee of the National met in Mrs. C's parlor. Sister Mary arrived.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Tues. Jan 26, 1897 Ther
28th National A. W. S. A. and
9th one outside of Washington D.C.
Des Monies - Iowa
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending the 28th National A. W. S. A. conference, which was the 9th one held outside of Washington D.C., in Des Monies - Iowa.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Wed. Jan. 27, 1897 Ther.
National Con.
Church - Des Moines I
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a national conference at a church in Des Moines, Iowa.

entries.fullText:
National Con --
Des Moines Iowa
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the National Convention in Des Moines, Iowa on January 28, 1897.

entries.fullText: National Con Des Moines
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the National Convention in Des Moines on January 29, 1897.

entries.fullText:
Left the Callanan's --
at 7. A. M -- Mrs Catt,
Miss Hay -- Mr Blackwell & Alice Rachel & Nicolas --
& self - the three stopped
off at different points --
-- I reached Chicago at
7.15 -- found dear Mrs
Gross at North Western
Station -- H. B. B. -- Alice
and Miss Hay went to
hotel -- had a
nice supper & chat
& went to bed tired
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Callanan's to Chicago with Mrs Catt, Miss Hay, Mr Blackwell, Alice Rachel, and Nicolas. She meets Mrs Gross at North Western Station and has supper with Alice and Miss Hay before going to bed.

entries.fullText:
Left Chicago on
11.50 train -- reached
Indianapolis -- 5. --
found Mrs. Sewall
at 242 - Penn St --
-- Rachel's little
Miriam glad to see
me -- She seemed pleased
with school and her home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Chicago and arrives in Indianapolis where she meets Mrs. Sewall and Rachel's little Miriam who is pleased with school and her home.

entries.fullText:
-- Mrs Zerelda Wallace
called -- Mrs Sewall
gave reception to members
of Legislature & all state officers & [?]
-- all Cornine women &
husbands -- a large
number came -- among
them the late Senator McDonalds
wife -- dressed in Corn
neck al-her -- Washington
days -- Mrs Sewall
wore her black velvet,
corn colored material silk --
I my garnet velvet &
point lace -- Lillians
black silk -- Corn neck
& short sleeves --
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Sewall gave a reception to members of the Legislature and all state officers and Cornine women and husbands. Among them was the late Senator McDonald's wife dressed in Corn neck al-her. Mrs. Sewall wore her black velvet, corn colored material silk.

entries.fullText:
In Indianapolis
Mrs Wallace & George
W. Julian at Lunch
-- Mrs Lillian Wright
gave reception
for me to the [young?]
people -- very large & nice
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Lillian Wright gave a reception for me to the young people, which was very large and nice.

entries.fullText:
At nine morning,
spoke before joint
sessions of Indiana
Legislature -- in the
Assembly chamber
for an hour -- packed
galleries -- & nearly
every members seat
filled --
At - 6.20 -- took
train -- with Mrs Ida
H. Harper - for home -
Mrs H. going to try to
go through old letters
& papers & write story
of S. B. As life --
pouring rain --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke before the joint sessions of Indiana Legislature and then took a train home with Mrs. Ida H. Harper.

entries.fullText:
Reached Rochester
at 9.05 -- all night --
found Sister
Mary well - &
Julia Ames - there
helper ditto --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester and found her sister Mary and Julia Ames there.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Mrs. Sweet at
work for me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home with Mrs. Sweet working for her.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs. Sweet taking
letters -- & I trying
to get caught up
with correspondence
Mrs. Harper doing
her own letters
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home with Mrs. Sweet and Mrs. Harper, catching up on correspondence.

people: with Miss Shaws nieces Nicola Shaw and Lola Green
entries.fullText:
Niece Lucy E. Anthony,
with Miss Shaws nieces
Nicola Shaw and Lola
Green arrived at 9.20
P M - to be here at
Miss Shaw's 50th birth-day.
-- Sunday 14 -- and mine the 15th
entries.summaryText: Niece Lucy E. Anthony, with Miss Shaws nieces Nicola Shaw and Lola Green arrived at 9.20 P M - to be here at Miss Shaw's 50th birth-day.

entries.fullText:
With the three girl
visitors -- all of them
went down town
Bought small
Mahogany writing desk
for front chamber
presented of Mrs.
Harper and Miss Shaw
entries.summaryText: With the three girl visitors -- all of them went down town. Bought small Mahogany writing desk for front chamber presented of Mrs. Harper and Miss Shaw.

entries.fullText: The three nieces met Rev Anna Shaw at station -- 5.55 - So we counted one more -- -- fully expected dear Mrs Gross was coming with Miss Shaw -- but she couldn't --- -- we supped & chatted -- &c --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with her three nieces and Rev Anna Shaw at home. They expected Mrs. Gross to come with Miss Shaw but she couldn't make it. They had supper and chatted.

entries.fullText: At an 8.20 breakfast dear niece Louise Mosher James arrived -- so we have two nieces and Miss Shaw two -- all hands -- 8 -- went to church -- a splendid sermon -- -- At evening -- we went to Douglass meeting in the Plymouth Church -- I presided - Anna spoke - also Mrs. Victoria Earle Mathews of 9 Murray St -- New York -- slightly colored -- Mr Thompson reported $100. collection -- It was a splendid crowd
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had breakfast with her niece Louise Mosher James and they all went to church. In the evening, they went to a Douglass meeting at Plymouth Church where Susan presided and Anna Shaw and Mrs. Victoria Earle Mathews spoke. Mr. Thompson reported a $100 collection.

entries.fullText:
My 77th birthday
reception given me at
Powers beautiful hall, by
22 women's clubs of the
city - All of our big
family went - the Powers
sent carriages for us all -
it was a splendid
gathering of Rochesters
very best people - Every
body delighted
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony celebrates her 77th birthday with a reception given by 22 women's clubs of Rochester at Powers beautiful hall.

entries.fullText:
M. Nicolas Shaw & Lola
Green - took the 9:50 P.M.
train - Lehigh Valley train for
Phila - Niece Louise &
sister May went to station
with them -
Before breakfast -
Miss Shaw went to
front steps - broom in hand
- & slipped & turned her left
ankle very badly - so that
Lucy E. had to telegraph to
Greenpoint L. Island - cancelling
her engagement for tomorrow night
Dr. Baldwin - our dear Dr.
Hamilton's niece - came & took
charge
entries.summaryText: M. Nicolas Shaw and Lola Green leave for Phila on the Lehigh Valley train. Miss Shaw injures her ankle before breakfast and Dr. Baldwin takes charge.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary and self went to
Spencerport - 8.10. A.M. to take
a last look of our mother's
oldest & only sister - Amy Read
Howe - cousin Nancy Howe
Clark! - her only remaining
daughter - Emily Clark
Griggs - & husband A. Irving
Griggs - brought the remains
of the loved and loving mother
from the Westford - Otsego to where
she passed on to the beyond
in the A. M. of Thursday - Feb. 11-
- Cousin Nancy was born
May 26. 1811 - [?] was
85 years and nine months of age -
several of Rev Lemuel Clark's
nieces & grand nieces & nephews
came to the burial. -
Mr Griggs returned to New York
on the Empire State train, &
Cousin Emily came home with
us -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary went to Spencerport to attend the funeral of their mother's oldest sister, Amy Read Howe. They were accompanied by Nancy Howe Clark, Emily Clark Griggs, and her husband A. Irving Griggs. Several of Rev Lemuel Clark's nieces & grand nieces & nephews came to the burial.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Miss Shaws ankle
very much better - and
she & Lucy took Black
Diamond - Lehigh Valley
train at 11.45 - Neither
of us went to station -
Cousin Emily very
nervous - needing to be
quieted - all the time -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at home while Miss Shaw and Lucy took the Black Diamond train at 11.45. Cousin Emily was very nervous and needed to be quieted all the time.

entries.fullText: At home and working at letters - .
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and working on letters on February 19, 1897.

entries.fullText: At home. Niece Louise still with us -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and her niece Louise was still with her on February 20, 1897.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Harper niece
Louise - sister Mary and self
all went to Church - Dr.
G. Preached on Washington
& great men--
All the past
week Julia home
helping her mother
care for her sick
father and sister
Mary doing all of the
work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church with family and hears a sermon on Washington. Julia has been helping her sick family members while Mary does all the work.

entries.fullText:
To our surprise
Julia came - reporting
her father still alive.
It was a great relief
to feel that Sister
Mary could have have help
for the middle of today
entries.summaryText: Julia reports that her father is still alive, providing relief for Sister Mary who needs help.

entries.fullText:
Mary Lynch worked
to day - Julia swept
parlors & dear Louise
help her dust & put
in order - I am
really in the garret
now for sure - &
the going over letters
& papers is begun.
All went to Church
supper - at 6.20 - Mr. G,
asked Mary to tell what then
Washington is - but didn't
ask me - so I asked myself
to say the word - that I thought
George decidedly human since
he bought & sold slaves - &
when they ran away followed
& caught them - which
seemed to shock Mr. G.
entries.summaryText: Mary Lynch worked, Julia swept, and Louise helped her dust and put things in order. They went to a Church supper and Mr. G asked Mary about Washington, but didn't ask Susan. Susan thought George was decidedly human since he bought and sold slaves and caught them when they ran away, which seemed to shock Mr. G.

entries.fullText:
At home - & at
work in garret on old
letters with Mrs Harper
- Julia's father no better -
but she since monday has
come down at 8 - & gone
back at .6 -- it is very
hard for her & also very
hard for sister Mary - for
she will do all the work alone
- except - had a woman
to iron to day - Julia swept
the front chamber-
After supper Louise
& self called at Mary
Hallowells - Will Stout & wife
& Mary Pratt there - Sarah
Willis been very ill -
entries.summaryText: Susan worked on old letters with Mrs. Harper. Julia's father was not doing well and Julia had to come down at 8 and go back at 6. Mary will do all the work alone except for having a woman to iron. After supper, Susan and Louise called at Mary Hallowell's where Will Stout, his wife, and Mary Pratt were. Sarah Willis had been very ill.

entries.fullText:
At home all day -
working in garret with
Mrs Harper and Mrs
Sweet -

At Eve - Niece
Louise & I called
on Mrs Dix - sister
Mary went to concert
with Mrs Cook -

At near 10 - a telegram
came from Anna R.
Simmons and Emma J
Cranmer - Pierre - South
Dakota - saying "Suffrage
Amendment passed the
Legislative Branch" -

So that gives the National
work till election 1898!!
all hands must put shoulder
to the wheel
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a telegram from Anna R. Simmons and Emma J Cranmer stating that the Suffrage Amendment passed the Legislative Branch.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Mrs Sweet taking early
recollections of father and mother
Telegram came of death
of Mrs. Maud Humphrey
Warsaw - funeral to be on
Monday - & Mr. H. wants
me to be present & say a
few words! - it is most
unexpected & shocking - she
leaves two children - a son and daughter
Niece Louise left on
Black Diamond - Lehigh Valley train
11.45 A.M. - it will be two weeks
Sunday A.M. since she came -
we have had a nice visit from
her - she is most unselfish - &
lovely - gave her a coffee & sent
her husband an orange spoon
Spent P.M. talking about
mother and father - Mrs Sweet
taking it in short-hand
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a telegram informing her of the death of Mrs. Maud Humphrey and is asked to say a few words at the funeral.

entries.fullText:
At home
all day - Mrs. H.
went Mechanichs
Institute to see it
with Mrs Erving -
Uncle John Anthony's
eldest son Joseph
Anthony - died this
evening - at his home - in
Los Angeles, California.
Where he had lived for
several years with his
daughter Jessie Anthony -
they had built a new
House the last summer
& just settled in it a few
weeks - moved there from
Coleta - Whiteside County - Ill -
- he leaves two sons & two
daughters - all over
there in or near Los Angeles.
entries.summaryText: Joseph Anthony, Uncle John Anthony's eldest son, died in Los Angeles, California. He had recently moved there from Coleta, Whiteside County, Illinois with his daughter Jessie Anthony. He leaves behind two sons and two daughters.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs. H, Sister Mary & self
went to church in a
brisk snow storm -
in P.M. bright &
lovely - Mr. Gannett
preached on the
[?] on Abbotts
sermon on the
story of Jonah -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her companions went to church in a snow storm. Mr. Gannett preached on the story of Jonah.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Maude S Humphry
wife of L. H. Humphry
of Warsaw funeral
today - Sister Mary &
self & Mrs Sanford
took the 7.00 A.M. train
were met by Mrs Dr.
Gonnlock & taken to
their house to dinner -
services at 2 - immense
quantities of roses -
- a fearful blank left
- wife & mother snatched from
husband, two daughters Bessie,
Maude & one son Osias -
- all were perfectly heroic -
took the 5. P.M. train
& reached home for 7. supper
- a snowy, windy cold day -
entries.summaryText: Attended funeral of Maude S Humphry in Warsaw.

entries.fullText:
At home
plodding on
biography papers
entries.summaryText: Working on biography papers at home.

entries.fullText: Wea. Wed. March 3, 1897 Ther.
entries.summaryText: Short entry on March 3, 1897.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Thur. March 4, 1897 Ther.

Deep into old papers and letters -
entries.summaryText: Short entry on March 4, 1897, mentioning going through old papers and letters.

entries.fullText:
Looking over the
old letters of
fathers - that have
been for years and years
in mothers little green
stocking box in his
wood-shed - also
looking if the old
papers Eugene Mosher
left in an old velise -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home looking over old letters and papers.

entries.fullText:
At 3. 22 - P.M. I
went to Station & met
Miss Genevieve Lel Hawley
from Canajoharie - who
has come to try & see if
she is the right person
to be my secretary - Gave
up Mrs Sweet because
didn't feel able to pay
her price $2. a day - but
fear I shall find nothing
equal to her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Miss Genevieve Lel Hawley to potentially be her secretary and considers options after deciding not to hire Mrs. Sweet.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Harper - Miss Hawley
sister Mary & self went
to church -
- Mrs Gannett
called me aside - to tell me
Mrs. Coonly wrote her
asking her to make peace
with Miss Anthony because
she was to marry Prof. [????] -
- Wrote Mrs. C. in the
evening - that I had
expected she would
keep her promise to
herself inform me - if she
changed her mind - &
decided to accept his overtures
At 4 P.M. went over
to Mrs. Willis who was better &
then spent evening with Mary
Hallowell & had old
fashioned visit - alone with her
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Coonly wrote to Mrs. Gannett asking her to make peace with Miss Anthony because she was to marry Prof. [????].

entries.fullText:
[Left] At home -
Took new plain satin
[?] to Mrs. Tillam to get the
pink front taken out - & cream
white put in - also went
to Dr. Requa's - front teeth
gums are swollen
Letters from Maggie
& Mrs Stanton proposing
to spend the summer
vacation with us -
The California W. S. Am't
Bill defeated this evening in
the Assembly by 44 to 26 -
and the Senate by -
entries.summaryText: Visited Mrs. Tillam and Dr. Requa. Received letters from Maggie and Mrs. Stanton proposing to spend the summer vacation with us. The California W. S. Am't Bill was defeated in the Assembly and the Senate.

entries.fullText:
Lecture Auburn N. Y.
Presbyterian Church
Charles G. Adams -
whose wife is daughter
of Hicks Anthony - son
of grand-father Anthony's
brother - John - that is of
my great-uncle John Anthony
of Union Springs - Cayuga Co.
Left Rochester on 7.40 train
reached Auburn at 12.20 -
found dear Eliza Wright Oates
not down stairs - has been ill
a month
The Auburn P. E. club met
in Mrs Os parlors - at 2 P.M.
Mrs Jemima Kellogg there - Mr and
Mrs Adams called - she bringing a
lovely bunch of yellow roses
The rain poured and the
audience was small -
not over 200 - and I did hate
to take the $50 - it does hurt
me to feel a Com. out of pocket
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Auburn, NY and visited the Auburn P. E. club. She also mentions people she met and the small audience.

entries.fullText:
Left Auburn on the 2.50
train - had a pleasant
visit - Mrs. Emma Ewing
the teacher of cooking there -
found the type-writing
machine had come from
Rachel Foster Avery - it belongs
to the National U.S.A.
Sister Mary and Mrs Harper
were over to church to hear
Mrs Garretts paper on
Quakerism -
Letter from Mrs Upton
saying she had the Dozon
$1,000 note, also the Green
$500 note in tin box with her
bank in Warren - all right
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Auburn and received a letter from Mrs. Upton regarding some notes.

entries.fullText: Wea. Thur. March 11, 1897 Ther.

Wea. Fri. March 12, 1897 Ther.
Booker Washington of
the Tuskeegee School
Alabama - lecture this eve'g
entries.summaryText: Booker Washington of the Tuskeegee School in Alabama gave a lecture this evening.

entries.fullText:
At Home -
This P.M. Mrs Harper
called me to attic and
read her first five
chapters in S. B. A. down
to 1850 - a very readable
or listenable story - just
of girl-school and teaching
days!!
The P. E. Club's
sociable at Dan. M.
Anthony's this evening -
a rainy night - but
a large and nice musical
- Julia went to Chic. -
to see her sick father -
all the rest - Harper, Hawley
Mary and self to the sociable -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper reads Susan B. Anthony's story down to 1850. The P. E. Club's sociable at Dan. M. Anthony's.

entries.fullText:
Spent - my first
day in reading over
old letters - beginning with
1850 - very trying to the
eyes - such pale ink -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day reading old letters from 1850.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Harper and self went
to church - Mr. Garrett's
subject, "Exhileration from
high ideals" - good -
In evening - Sister Mary
called at Eliza
Wolcotts - & Mrs Harper
and self at the Garrett's -
- Several girls, Miss
Otis - Walker - Blachard all
dissented from Mr G's saying
there was no big deal in
playing cards!!
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper and Susan B. Anthony went to church and heard Mr. Garrett's sermon. In the evening, they visited Eliza Wolcotts and the Garrett's. Several girls dissented from Mr. G's saying there was no big deal in playing cards.

entries.fullText:
At Home -
Mrs Sweet came and took a lot
of letter dictation - full 3 hours
- Mrs Harper and sister May went
down town - Miss Hawley
worked on old letters - in attick
Mailed by "me too" - letter to
Miss Willard - on absurdity of
Women's coming out - now
after all decent papers had
protested, yellow journalism - and
Pugilism - and shouting me
too protest &c
Washington and South Dakota
have on hand amendment
campaigns up to Nov. 1898 -
The W. C. T. U's already showing
that they mean to wage a
prohibition suffrage battle
strange they cannot see that
suffrage people should carry
Amt, their one question to the people!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home, dictating letters with Mrs. Sweet. Mrs. Harper and sister May went downtown. Susan wrote a letter to Miss Willard about the absurdity of women's coming out. She also mentioned the amendment campaigns in Washington and South Dakota and the W.C.T.U.'s plan to wage a prohibition suffrage battle.

entries.fullText: At home -
entries.summaryText: At home.

entries.fullText:
Took the 9.05 train for
Albany - H.M. Mills met me
at station - found Mrs Chapman,
Mrs Catt, Dr. M. P. Jacobi, and Eliz.
Burrill Curtis at Stanwix Hotel
- at 3. P.M. took carriage to
Capitol - Senate chamber occupied
so were taken to the Judiciary
Comm's room - senator
Lexow - Chairman - Senator
L. H. Humphrey - introduced
us - but first Mrs. Frances
Scott - with black long hair and
pale face - read her Anti
address - then I spoke - then
Mrs. Mills - Jacobi and Catt - then
Mrs Cromwell of Albany gave a
most airy nothing - and Mrs
Humphrey insisted that Mrs Catt
should reply to her - No rest
after supper returned to New York and
I went - Syracuse with Miss Mills
reached her home at midnight
- I felt it would be the
last time I should ever stoop
to plead before such a set of "boys"
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Albany to speak before the Judiciary Committee, meets with various women's rights activists, and returns to New York before traveling to Syracuse with Miss Mills.

entries.fullText:
Had arranged with Mr
J. B. Pond to lecture at his
house - Bergen Avenue - Jersey City
this evening - but all [?????] & so
begged me to postpone -
so it was given up for this year
Left Syracuse on the
Empire State Express, and
reached home before 4. P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had to postpone her lecture in Jersey City due to unforeseen circumstances and returned home to Syracuse.

entries.fullText:
At home -
working in the garrett
over old letters with
Mrs Harper
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home in Syracuse working on old letters with Mrs. Harper in the garrett.

entries.fullText: Miss Hawley - at work unfolding & ironing out the old letters & clippings
entries.summaryText: Miss Hawley is at home and working on unfolding and ironing old letters and clippings.

entries.fullText: Went to church -- Mr. Gannet gave notice of Mrs. Sanford's reception to Sister Mary on her 70th birth day - with a very beautiful word for her & her older sister --
entries.summaryText: Attended church where Mr. Gannet announced Mrs. Sanford's reception for Sister Mary's 70th birthday and spoke beautifully about her and her older sister.

entries.fullText:
Did not go to
the Business meeting -
of the [?] Co. Club - this
evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not attend the Business meeting of the [?] Co. Club.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary's 70th Birthday
and it came on a
Monday - 70 years ago -
Mrs. Mary Thayer Sanford
20 James st - Rochester - N.Y.
gave reception in honor of
Sister Mary at her home -
- The day was lovely - Spring -
and large numbers called -
- A nice block cloth cape prettily
trimmed - & 70 gold dollars -
were publicly presented by Mrs.
Sanford & Mrs. Greenleaf -
Mrs. Harper, Sister Mary & self
stayed to supper - Mrs. Greenleaf,
Dr. & Mrs. Lozier, Dr. & Mrs. Willis
Mrs. Perry & Mrs. Millar --everything
went off beautifully --
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary's 70th Birthday celebration in Rochester - N.Y.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Worked at old letters
all day with Mrs. H.
& finished them down
or up to 1860 - So
we are ready for
Mrs. Sweet to begin
taking my story of
that Decade from
50 to 60 on Monday --
It has taken
full two weeks of
close work to go
through with the letters
of the ten years from
1850 to 1860 --
entries.summaryText: Working on old letters with Mrs. H. and preparing for Mrs. Sweet to begin taking my story of that decade from 50 to 60 on Monday.

entries.fullText: All but Sister Mary - Mrs. Harper, Miss Hawley and self went to church - good sermon - began promptly at 10.00 - again called at Port Office and got letters - In evening Mrs H, and self went to Charles and Louise Fitch's - 'at home' - Sunday evening - no one else there - so had a nice visit talked over publisher for biography
entries.summaryText: Went to church, visited Port Office, and spent the evening at Charles and Louise Fitch's discussing the publisher for a biography.

entries.fullText: At home Mrs Sweet came to take story - beginning with 1850 - - in forenoon - Miss Hawley to keep on taking letters - and working on old papers - This evening offered Miss H, $5 a week for the month of April to do everything I wanted as well as stenography & type writing & she accepted -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Sweet came to take a story and Miss Hawley was offered $5 a week to do everything Susan B. Anthony wanted, including stenography and type writing.

entries.fullText:
At home
in attic - Ms Sweet
came again - took
1854 - 5 & 6 - story -
It fairly tries
me to think over
& talk over the
never ceasing [?]
of those days -
always trying to
stir up others to
go & speak. -
entries.summaryText: Ms Sweet came to visit and they talked about the past and Susan's efforts to encourage others to speak.

entries.fullText:
At home
Ms Sweet took
1857 story -
Ms Harper cannot
believe that I was
not a speaker then -
but only a getter up
of meetings for
others & to make their
speeches -
entries.summaryText: Ms Sweet visited again and they discussed Susan's role in organizing meetings and speeches for others, rather than speaking herself. Ms Harper expressed disbelief at this.

entries.fullText:
Dictating story
to Mrs Sweet
entries.summaryText: Dictating story to Mrs Sweet

entries.fullText:
Mrs Hanish Mrs
Clark & her daughter
Mabel - who is
in Cornell University -
came to tea this
P.M. -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Hanish, Mrs Clark, and Mabel from Cornell University came to tea

entries.fullText:
at home
working on the decade
between 1850 & 1860
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home working on the decade between 1850 and 1860.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self
went to church -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary went to church.

entries.fullText:
At home
at 2.80 - was at
Church Parlor to
see & hear Miss
Charlotte Coffin
Wilkinson - the
grand-daughter of
dear Sam'l J. May -
give lecture on the
sweat-shop system
- she is lovely - about
25
entries.summaryText: Attended a lecture by Charlotte Coffin Wilkinson on the sweat-shop system at Church Parlor.

entries.fullText:
At home
The Cort Sociable
of the Political Equality
Club at our house -
reminiscences the
order of exercises -
a large crowd
entries.summaryText: Hosted the Cort Sociable of the Political Equality Club at home with a large crowd.

entries.fullText:
At home -
This A.M. papers
announced the
death of the
dear - forsaken
woman - Mrs
Elizabeth R.
Tilton - on
Pacific Avenue
Brooklyn - N.Y.
She vastly less
sinning - than
sinned against
by her Pastor & husband -
- a sad - sad life
entries.summaryText: Mrs Elizabeth R. Tilton has died in Pacific Avenue Brooklyn - N.Y. She was sinned against by her Pastor & husband.

entries.fullText:
at home
The papers say that
Mrs Tilton died on
Tuesday - that at
her wish the fact was
kept quiet to save
revival of newspaper
gossip over her -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Tilton has died on Tuesday and her wish was to keep the fact quiet to avoid newspaper gossip over her.

entries.fullText: Went to Church
entries.summaryText: Went to Church

entries.fullText:
Brother Merritt's 62nd
birth day - how well I
remember the day he was
born_ in the nursery of
the new brick house --
April, 19 1824!! poor
dear mother - with her
eighth baby -- 41 years
of age -- Seventeen
years of the hey-day
of her life given to
bearing and rearing eight
children!! together
with the greatest amount
of drudgery with but
few of luxuries of life
entries.summaryText: Celebrated Brother Merritt's 62nd birthday and reflected on mother's life and hardships.

entries.fullText:
at home
one dull
monotonous
grind in [???]
old papers
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about being at home and going through old papers.

entries.fullText: at-home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about being at home.

entries.fullText:
Our dear mothers
little Eliza J. is
65 years to day - she
was born in the old
house at Battenville -
April 22, 1832 - and
died May 18, 1834-
- These are the lives
of Pierpoint she
used to repeat over
& over - & dear mother
got the Democrat to
re-publish it for
away back in thearly sixties at least
before Chronicle had appeared
Mr & Miss Kate
Gleason called this
evening
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Eliza J.'s birthday and reminisces about Pierpoint's life. She also mentions a visit from Mr. and Miss Kate Gleason.

entries.fullText:
At 5 p.m. went
down town to Dr
Regna's - door
closed - my big tooth
upper - on which the plate
is clasped - left hole - is
very [?] & lame - & swollen
In evening for [?] Mrs. Sweet,
Mrs. Kitridge, & Lou - Mr. & Mrs.
Osborne & Mr. Morse called
-Morse models in clay
& wants to make a
medallion of me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dr. Regna's and later has visitors including Mr. Morse who wants to make a medallion of her.

entries.fullText:
Went to Wilder Building
to see Dr Requa - the
Dentist - but not there
Letter from Mrs
Emma Shafter Howard
of Oakland - saying
my invitation for her
to visit us came to her
yesterday A.M. - that her
ticket was purchased -
& that her son couldn't
get it changed so she
could come this way -
- awfully sorry for any delay -
- & yet with Julia away
how could we have
waited on her ! but I
did want to see her before
she went home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to the dentist and receiving a letter from Mrs. Emma Shafter Howard of Oakland.

entries.fullText:
The 50th anniversary
Golden Wedding - of
James & Sargent
East [Amer???] - &
I am to be one of the
receiving ladies -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending the 50th anniversary Golden Wedding of James and Sargent in East [Amer???].

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Harper finished
first writing of chapter XIV --
which brings story down to 1861 --
-- I went to milliner,
shoemaker -- optician, banker
& Dentist -- yes & grocery store
in person -- & in P.M.
Mrs. H. went shopping --
Letter from Mrs. Eliza Wright
Osborne inviting me to spend
first two weeks in [?] with
her -- Mrs. Stanton to be there --
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper finished writing chapter XIV, Susan B. Anthony ran errands and received a letter from Mrs. Eliza Wright Osborne inviting her to spend two weeks with her and Mrs. Stanton.

entries.fullText:
To Church
sister Mary & self
entries.summaryText: Went to church with sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
To Church
sister Mary & self
entries.summaryText: Went to church with sister Mary.

entries.fullText: Wea. Wed. May 12, 1897 Ther.

people: Sister Mary - Mrs. Harper & self - Mrs. J. B. Greenleafs - Mrs James Sergeant & Mrs Dr Elizabeth J. French
entries.fullText: Sister Mary - Mrs. Harper & self took tea at Mrs. J. B. Greenleafs - with Mrs James Sergeant & Mrs Dr Elizabeth J. French - of Boston -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary, Mrs. Harper, and Susan B. Anthony had tea at Mrs. J. B. Greenleaf's with Mrs. James Sergeant and Mrs. Dr. Elizabeth J. French of Boston.

entries.fullText:
called at Mrs. Garrett
found them [?]
Prof. Ward. & dear Mrs.
Coonley at breakfast -
& they decided to take tea
with us tomorrow Saturday P.M.]
- The alliance doesn't
seem any better to me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Garrett and has breakfast with Prof. Ward and Mrs. Coonley. They plan to have tea the next day. She expresses her dissatisfaction with the alliance.

entries.fullText:
Harriet Stanton Blatch
is to sail this day for England -
has been over here since last
October with her mother - her
ward with her -

Harriet did sail this day

Mr. & Mrs Garrett - Prof.
Henry Ward of this city &
Mrs. Lydia Avery Coomley of
Chicago married March
- & just returned from a
trip to Florida & the
Bermuda Islands - were
at supper with us - Mrs.
Coomley seemed as good as
ever - but Mrs. Harper
said kept a close watch
of every word, gesture, &
look of mine - evidently to
satisfy herself as to any
feelings relation to the man
she had joined herself to
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony notes that Harriet Stanton Blatch is sailing to England. She also has supper with Mr. and Mrs. Garrett, Prof. Henry Ward, Mrs. Lydia Avery Coomley, and Mrs. Harper. Mrs. Harper seems to be watching Susan closely.

entries.fullText:
Went to Church
alone- Sister May
Mrs Harper-Miss Hawley
& Julia all at home-
- May, Mrs Harper &
self dined at Mr & Mrs
Pikes-22 Sumner &
with Mrs Emma J Ewing
the teacher-professor
of the Culinary Inst &
her husband at 2.30
At evening I called on
Mrs. Wm Hoyt Spring
Street- she walked out &
took [?] with me
Mr Wm Peck then - so
we couldn't talk over
what I wished to
Mrs Alice Lee Stratton of
Oakland California died
this morning--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to church, dined with friends, and called on Mrs. Wm Hoyt Spring. Mrs Alice Lee Stratton of Oakland California died.

entries.fullText:
At home - a
letter from Mrs Mary
Hout Roddis- New
Orleans-La with several
of my letters our dated
1854 - yellow & tattered
with its two score & three years.
The wife of our dear old
minister Rev N.H. Mann &
her friend Mrs Welch of Troy - here to tea with
us- no one called at evening
This was the first of
my "at homes"- but really
no one knows of it.
Received Oakland
[?] Ny. 25 with the sad
news that the wife of Hon
Frederick S Statton of
Oakland Cal died on
Sunday May 16th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from Mrs Mary Hout Roddis, had visitors for tea, and received sad news about the death of Hon Frederick S Statton's wife.

entries.fullText:
Letter from Mrs. Stanton
saying there is a void in
their hearts & home - learn
of Hattie & her Nora's
departure on Saturday - &
Wanting to have her mem's
published by same firm
as mine - & in same style
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Mrs. Stanton about Hattie and Nora's departure and wanting her memoirs published by the same firm as mine.

entries.fullText:
Working on biography
papers
entries.summaryText: Worked on biography papers.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home on May 20, 1897.

entries.fullText: Sister May & self went to Y.M.C.A. Hall to Mr. Morse's Studios - to look at medallion of I.S.A. - General of the P.E. Club there - but none pleased with it & sent over again in P.M. & sat for the [?]
entries.summaryText: On May 21, 1897, Susan B. Anthony and her sister May went to Y.M.C.A. Hall and Mr. Morse's Studios to look at a medallion of I.S.A. (General of the P.E. Club there), but were not pleased with it and sent it over again in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
At home
Cousin Ellen
Hoxier Squires son
Burt called in
P.M. - he & his wife
just home from nearly
two years in Colorado &
Kansas - his mother
had surgical operation
on Wednesday - & doing very
well - Burt has
grown stout & brown
& looks well
entries.summaryText: Cousin Ellen, Hoxier Squires son, and Burt visited Susan B. Anthony at home. Burt and his wife had just returned from a two-year trip to Colorado and Kansas. Burt's mother had a surgical operation and is doing well.

people: cousin Eleen Hoxie Squire's son Burt
entries.fullText:
Went to church
also Mrs. Harper - the
subject was "the Fine
Art of Giving & Taking
Advice" - both are
very different of
attainment - cousin
Eleen Hoxie Squire's son
Burt came to dinner
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to church and had dinner with cousin Eleen Hoxie Squire's son Burt and Mrs. Harper. The sermon was about the fine art of giving and taking advice.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Harper spent whole day cooking and purchasing a summer dress- & I in dictating letters to Miss Hawley & writing an equal umber with my own pen-
I feel hopeless-[?] Iam prevented from plunging into work waiting to be done- by the demands on [?] or read & write of the past-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day dictating letters and writing, feeling hopeless and prevented from working on other tasks.

entries.fullText:
The Oakland Cal -
Enquirer came- from
some friend - with the
Sad word that Mrs Alice
Lee Stratton died on
Sunday 16th - Heart trouble -
the paper said - she was
a lovely & grand woman
wife of Hon Fred. S. Stratton
of 1201 Harrison st - Oakland
wrote best I could to
Mr Stratton at once -
- Rev J.R. McLean
preached at the funeral -
Tuesday the 18th

Mrs Harper by & self
took drive with Mr
J. Thayer out East Ave
to Brighton & then tea
at his house [??] [??]
serves it
entries.summaryText: Received news of the death of Mrs Alice Lee Stratton and wrote to Mr Stratton. Went for a drive with Mr J. Thayer.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs H. went Y.W. C. A.
Taylor's to try on dress - The
Ex. Com. of P.E.Club met
Y. W. C. A. to [look?] a second
model - & all approved-
Went to Mr. Hass
shoemaker - but no
shoes ready
entries.summaryText: Mrs H. went to Y.W. C. A. and tried on a dress. Went to Mr. Hass shoemaker but shoes were not ready.

entries.fullText:
At home all day
Letter from Mrs. Catt saying
she wouldn't stop off here
this day--too great a
hurry to get home--&
to head quarters office
work--something mysterious--
says she Miss Shaw
& one other officer--promised
not to tell--are to resign at
end of this year--I wrote
her if all the young women
gone out--the Old almost
Octogenarian would have to
rush in & fill the gaps--
until a new lot of girls
came to the rescue--
A letter from F.E. Willard
shows she is far from a
well woman--Lady Henry
cables for her to go to England
as their doctors surpass America's
entries.summaryText: Received letters from Mrs. Catt and F.E. Willard. Mrs. Catt mentioned that Miss Shaw and another officer are to resign at the end of the year. F.E. Willard is not well and Lady Henry wants her to go to England.

entries.fullText:
Mrs [?art] here to talk
Medallion contract--
& sister M. & self to go to
[?] Morse's Studio to see
& sign--All hands at
Albert H. Morse's studio in
P.M.--accepted medallion--
sister M. signed contract &
S.B.A. gave check on powers
for $100--
entries.summaryText: Met with Mrs [?art] to discuss Medallion contract. Went to Albert H. Morse's studio with sister M. and accepted medallion. S.B.A. gave a check for $100.

entries.fullText:
Went to Church
Sister Mary also - Mr. G.
preached on Storage Batteries
- moral & country loving - as,
well as electricity - water, air,
good - only [?]
[?] as dinner
while I should call it
Political sore-headism

In ev'g Mrs Harper
& self called on Mrs
Kent Bromley Troupe street -
_______________
Decoration Day -
Julia went home - Churchville
at 800 A.M. & returned
at 7.00 evening -
entries.summaryText: Attended church and visited Mrs. Kent Bromley on Decoration Day.

entries.fullText:
This is the day of
Decoration celebration -
all banks & stores closed
We remained home all day -
Julia's mother came at
evening -
Mrs Johnson - who
is both mother & father to
Jennie Hughes two older
boys - second wife of Dan
Johnson - called at evening - &
we had delightful chat - no
one else - this is the
3rd Monday since it has
been told I would be at home
entries.summaryText: Stayed home for Decoration Day and had a pleasant conversation with Mrs. Johnson.

entries.fullText:
At Home -
Working all day
read letters of 1868
& 1869 - living over
those days of struggle
with the Revolution &
Army people -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on letters from 1868 and 1869 and remembers the struggle with the Revolution and Army people.

entries.fullText:
at home -
Sun shining & warmer
Letter from Rev Shaw -
brother Merritt & others -
Tea at Mrs Sanfords -
wrote Mrs Robbins - [?]
Council - voting "no" to
Mrs Dickinson's resignation -
with "yes" to sundry other proposals
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from Rev Shaw and brother Merritt, attends tea at Mrs. Sanfords, and participates in a council meeting where they vote against Mrs. Dickinson's resignation and approve other proposals.

entries.fullText: Working on letters & papers
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on letters and papers at home on June 3, 1897.
Susan B. Anthony was at home on June 4, 1897.

entries.fullText: Learned that Mrs Laura J. Ramsdell died Thursday night - and we had not seen notice in papers - I stopped with her over 40 years ago - at Livonia - where she then resided - she is about my age - Brother Daniel's son D.R.A. Jr - came in P.M. - on way to N.Y. & Washington - he hopes to get the Leavenworth P.O. & is to be married to Miss Bessie Havens on his return home -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Laura J. Ramsdell died, D.R.A. Jr visited and is getting married.

entries.fullText: Miss Shaw to arrive this A.M. - Nephew D.R. Jr left on 9.05 train for New York He is a good wholesome looking and behaving young man - 6 ft. 4 inches
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw arrived and D.R. Jr left for New York.

entries.fullText:
[Batavia - N.Y.
Mrs. Helen M. Sherwin - station
415 East Main st. - Postponed]
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Helen M. Sherwin postponed meeting in Batavia.

entries.fullText:
In Auburn
at noon came Miss
Emily Howland of
Sherwood - & at 5.20
came Mrs Harper -
so the guests increase in
number & the rains pour
entries.summaryText: Emily Howland and Mrs. Harper arrived in Auburn and the weather was rainy.

entries.fullText: [sewing ?] all day
entries.summaryText: Sewing all day in Auburn on June 9, 1897.

entries.fullText:
In Auburn
Mrs. Harper left
at 2.50 . P.M.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper left Auburn at 2:50 PM on June 10, 1897.

entries.fullText: A rainy day -
entries.summaryText: Rainy day in Auburn.

entries.fullText:
Mrs S. & self had a 2nd
drive at the Lake -
Mr & Mrs riley of
Ithica arrived at
7 P.M -
Mrs. Osborne invited
friends to meet - Mrs
Stanton & self - the
son of W. H. Seward -
wife & daughter Mrs
- Allen came - aso
Mrs [Cheeselia ? Cheesebro ?] - of
Canandaigua - daughter
of Mrs Worden [inserted above the name is B. Miller] - the
sister of Mrs Seward -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. S and Susan B. Anthony had a second drive at the Lake. Mr. and Mrs. Riley arrived from Ithica. Mrs. Osborne invited friends to meet Mrs. Stanton and Susan B. Anthony. Several people including Mrs. Cheesebro from Canandaigua, daughter of Mrs. Worden and sister of Mrs. Seward, attended.

entries.fullText: In Auburn
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry about being in Auburn on June 13, 1897.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Stanton [?] & [?]
& self left Auburn on
the 2.50 P.M. train - they
stopped at Geneva - &
I came on home - to
find that nephew D. R. Jr.
had arrived Sunday
P.M. - and left this A.M.
Mrs Harper gone to
Cornell University [?]
- Sidney Morse - Sculptor
at tea - Mrs Warner of
Oakland Cal. called - Mrs
McLean of Mississippi
also - Mr Joseph [Bloss ?]
& wife & Mrs Sweet -
entries.summaryText: On June 14, 1897, Susan B. Anthony traveled from Auburn with Mrs. Stanton, stopped at Geneva, and returned home to find her nephew had arrived. She also mentions various visitors, including Mrs. Harper, Sidney Morse, Mrs. Warner, Mrs. McLean, Mr. Joseph [Bloss ?], and Mrs. Sweet.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary & self attended the acting Presidents reception - Prof. Lattimore - at Powers Gallery - very many of Rochester's University graduates there - Dr E. M. Moore to be 83 in July the central figure -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary attended a reception at Powers Gallery hosted by the acting President. Many graduates from Rochester's University were present, and Dr E. M. Moore, who was to turn 83 in July, was the central figure.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on June 17, 1897.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on June 18, 1897.

entries.fullText: Wea. Sat. June 19, 1897 Ther.

At home - went
to church alone
and at eve - called
at May Hallowells &
had nice chat
en route home called
at Charles & Louise Fitch
and talked of nephew
Burt's chances of getting
work as reporter on news
paper-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to church alone and visited May Hallowells and Charles & Louise Fitch. They talked about Burt's chances of getting work as a reporter on a newspaper.

entries.fullText:
Brother D.R.'s son
Daniel Read Anthony Jr -
Bessie S Havens -
married this day -
& started for New York
- the Waldorf - & their
bridal trip to the old world
- so brother D.R. & Sister Anna
Osborne are left quite
alone - their eldest - Maude
married a year ago - &
living in Utah - their
son married this day - &
their two little girls - [?]
there -
entries.summaryText: Daniel Read Anthony Jr and Bessie S Havens get married and start their honeymoon trip to the old world.

entries.fullText:
Went with Sister Mary
this A.M. to Ward's
Museum - Mr. Charles [name underlined]
Ward's work shop to do
the medallion of self -
finished to perfection - all
said - The cost [underlined] - in paper
boxes - ready to deliver is [to ?]
be 26 cts each - & in wooden
boxes to be sent by mail or
Express 28 cts each -
Mrs West, Mrs Black & Mrs
Fermer are the Com. in
charge of selling them -
25 per cent which at
present price - means 25
on each medallion is to
go to the National Suffrage
Fund -
This day we
begin to go into the
shorter days -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to Ward's Museum and discusses the cost of medallions with Mrs. West, Mrs. Black, and Mrs. Fermer. They agree to donate 25% of the proceeds to the National Suffrage Fund.

entries.fullText:
This is the day set for
the 3rd reading of the women
Parliamentary vote bill in
the British House of Commons
Do hope the bill will
pass & become law.
Brit Queens Jubilee that
- closing her 60 years reign -
caused adjournment of
Parliament
Julia went home
this P.M. & returned in
evening - on Business relative
to her father's death -
Mrs Tenney sewing for
me all of this week
& two days of last -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony hopes that the women Parliamentary vote bill will pass and become law.

entries.fullText:
at home
very hot & sultry with
thunder. Letter from
nephew A.A. Mosher
saying he would be at
Adams - that nephew
D.R. Jr & bride would
dine with them on
Friday & sail on
Saturday - I called up to
help him [mothers?] this it [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from her nephew A.A. Mosher and plans to help him with something related to his mother.

entries.fullText:
Brother Daniels only son
D.R. A. Jr. - and Paul
E. Havens youngest
daughter - Elizabeth
sail for the old
world to day - [?]
So the Bride &
groom dined at
nephew A.A. Moshers
this day & sailed
the next
Mrs Sanford her
last call this P.M,
before start, for
San Francisco
entries.summaryText: Brother Daniels' son, D.R. A. Jr., and Paul E. Havens' daughter, Elizabeth, sail for the old world. Bride and groom dine at nephew A.A. Mosher's. Mrs. Sanford makes her last call before leaving for San Francisco.

entries.fullText:
[First paragraph below is crossedmout]
Quarterly annuity
due to do - forgot
to write the Penn
Life 9Mutual0 Life
Ins. Co.

D.R. Jr. 7 his Elizabeth
sailed for England
on the Umbria [U is underlined twice] this
day
entries.summaryText: D.R. Jr. and Elizabeth sail for England on the Umbria. Quarterly annuity due but forgotten to write to Penn Mutual Life Insurance Co.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary - Miss Hawly & self went to Church - Julia went home yesterday forenoon - to see about her fathers insurance policies - & returned this [?] - At evening Mrs Harper & self called at Mr Gleasons & then spent evening at Mrs Greenleafs
entries.summaryText: Went to church with Sister Mary and Miss Hawly, visited Mr. Gleason and Mrs. Greenleaf in the evening.

entries.fullText: Dr & Mrs Madeline Sanford started for California this P.M. Began reading up letters & Diary Books of the decade between 1870 & 1880 this day - The plot thickens - four months of hardest kind of work for both Mrs Harper & self - with constant help of type writer - & our first writing done to 1870 -
entries.summaryText: Dr. and Mrs. Madeline Sanford left for California. Started reading letters and diary books from 1870 to 1880.

entries.fullText:
-
Working on letters [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and working on letters.

entries.fullText:
Unitarian Pic nic -
Forest Lawn - on Lake
Ontario - very heavy
rains all last night
& this forenoon - So
Pic nic abandoned
Letters from brothers
D.R. & J. M. - the former
writing but not sister Anna
- & brother Merritt thinks he
cannot come - but have written
him he must not break
the pleasure - by preventing the
meeting of all of us [fam ?] left
of mothers & fathers children -
At evening went to call
on Dr Sherman Ricker & [?]
brot me home in her Phaeton -
she is a philosophied Doctor -
She had just returned from
Womens' Con at Buffalo
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a Unitarian picnic at Forest Lawn on Lake Ontario, but it is abandoned due to heavy rains. She receives letters from her brothers and goes to visit Dr. Sherman Ricker, who is a philosophied Doctor and had just returned from a Women's Convention in Buffalo.

entries.dateText:
[Handwritten above Wea. the words - hot & bright -]

Wea. THUR. JULY 1, 1897 Ther.
entries.fullText:
This is sister [Greelman's ?]
79th birthday - all of
hers are gone save niece
Maggie McLean Baker - & her
three boys & one girl -
Wrote letters about the
Adams Mass reunion -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her sister's birthday and writing letters about the Adams Mass reunion.

entries.fullText:
Went to Dr [Regan's ?] &
had three teeth filled -
Deposited in Powers Bank
my $200. Annuity for June 26 -
Sister Mary went to
Unitarian Pic nic at
Forest Lawn - a hot day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about going to the dentist, depositing money, and her sister Mary going to a picnic at Forest Lawn.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs Harper took 10.55
train for Mayville Chau. Co -
to visit her sister - Mrs.
- just before leaving told
me some one had taken a
silver stick-pin out of
silver jewelry box - that had
been in her upper drawer
ever since she had been here - &
she knew it was there when she
came!! - This with her V. loss
of Thursday 23 - is most remarkable
Time will I trust develope
her mistake in both cases !!
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper visited her sister in Mayville Chau. Co and reported a missing silver stick-pin.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self
with G.L. Hawley went
to church - the subject
A Sobered County showing
that we were parting with
much of our conceit &
spread-eagle oratory as a
people -
This days
heat phenomenal -
- hottest in 26 years -
after dinner Julia
went home to Churchville
her brother Will ill
with Malarial fever -
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Sister Mary and G.L. Hawley. Julia went home to Churchville due to her brother's illness.

entries.fullText:
Another tremendously
hot day - we just
lay & sat round in
next to no clothes
Julia returned at
6 - Lillian Ready
called & remained to
tea - she is a dress maker
& works with Mrs Barnard.
entries.summaryText: Julia and Lillian Ready visited and had tea. Lillian Ready is a dressmaker who works with Mrs. Barnard.

entries.fullText:
Hot - but a little
more air stirring - Sister
Mary & self went down
to Beadle & Carrolls store - & got
a black & white shirt waist
Letter from cousin
D.R. reads - Sarah [Burback ?] -
saying they would go to Adams
the 29 - also from Uncle
Joshua Anthony's Joshua
saying they would go -
entries.summaryText: Susan and Sister Mary went to Beadle & Carrolls store and got a black & white shirt waist. Susan received letters from cousin D.R. and Uncle Joshua Anthony's Joshua about going to Adams.

entries.fullText: hot - hot - weather
entries.summaryText: Hot weather at home on July 7, 1897.

entries.fullText: hot weather
entries.summaryText: Hot weather at home on July 8, 1897.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry stating that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
at home
Mrs Harper
returned at 2 P.M.
Weather awfully
hot -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry stating that she was at home with Mrs Harper who returned at 2 P.M. She also mentioned that the weather was awfully hot.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self
went to Church -
Mrs Garret to leave
for White Mountains
on Thursday next -
awfully hot - just
felt as if the heat could
not be endured another
minute - but in P.M,
there came the heaviest
thunder storm - it seemed
me - I ever knew-
- & so broke up the
fearfully hot spell -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary and Mrs Garret attend church and discuss upcoming travel plans. A heavy thunderstorm breaks up a hot spell.

entries.fullText:
at home
Julia doing the
washing in lovely
rain water - but
the lowry showery
day prevented good
drying - so lost in
part the soft water
good -
entries.summaryText: Julia does laundry with rain water, but the showery day prevents good drying.

entries.fullText:
Mother & Father married just
80 years ago this day - July 13, 1817
entries.summaryText: Mother & Father's 80th wedding anniversary.

entries.fullText:
at home
writing letters &
getting last things
done before leaving
home - would
that I were not
to have this [week?]
in my home staying
I have now been
at home more months
together than in any
one of the last 30 or
40 years - and
would love to have
been let alone here
for the entire year -
entries.summaryText: Preparing to leave home, wishes to have been left alone for the entire year.

entries.fullText: Mr. Sargent took Mrs. H & self to their summer house - Sunset cottage Summerland - Alexandria Bay - St Lawrence River - arriving the Thousand Islands - left R. at 11:00 - arrived Bay at 7:05 Their little launch did not arrive until 7:20 - so we reached the island & had an eight Oclock supper - only Mrs. Pond - here so Mrs. Harper & self - [?] their guests for the coming week.
entries.summaryText: Mr. Sargent took Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. H to their summer house in Summerland, Alexandria Bay, St Lawrence River, Thousand Islands. They arrived at the Thousand Islands and had supper with Mrs. Pond.

entries.fullText: This day is set for us to go the Thousand Islands to James & Josephine Sargents summer cottage. Left home the day earlier - so this day - am at the lovely River Island home - all quiet as need be - Rev. Asa Lane & wife & daughter Mrs. Hanford & her four sons & one girl - have cottage [?] [?] in the Force Cottage since Mrs. Wilkinson of Phila with her baby boy & four girls of her husband - who is a [?] for Wannamaker of Phila
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at James and Josephine Sargent's summer cottage in River Island, Thousand Islands. She spent time with Rev. Asa Lane, Mrs. Hanford, and Mrs. Wilkinson and her family.

entries.fullText: Planned to make the Thousand Island trip but didn't - the rest went to the club house at Bay
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony planned to make the Thousand Island trip but didn't.

entries.fullText: Planned to make the circuit of the Islands but a severe storm came up - so didn't go much to my relief for I must say I feel best on terra firma.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony planned to make the circuit of the Islands but didn't due to a severe storm.

entries.fullText:
At Summerland
a quiet day
at 2 P.M. - all four
went for the day - took
the Island steamer &
made a 40 milestrip
around among the
2,400 Islands - not
1. but 2,400 islands -
Found Mr. Staples
& son in law Benitt
of Washington. Millard & Biggs
at the Bay - keeping the
Thousand Island Hotel
reporting very dull season.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and three others took a 40-mile trip around the 2,400 islands of Summerland, finding acquaintances at the Bay who reported a dull season.

entries.cityOrState: Summerland - Alexandria Bay - St. Lawrence River
entries.fullText:
At Mr. & Mrs. Sargents
Sunset Cottage
Summerland - Alexandria
Bay - St. Lawrence River
at home all the day
took a sleep in the
hammock in forenoon -
thunder & a two
hours sleep in my
lovely bed - during a long
& beautiful rain-
after supper Mr. S.
too us to the Bay -
letter from sister Mary
saying Miss Hawley had
left at 1:20 P.M. Monday -
Julia at her mothers in
Churchville - all of Sunday
& Monday til 8:30 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at Mr. & Mrs. Sargents' Sunset Cottage in Summerland, taking a nap in the hammock and enjoying a long and beautiful rain. In the evening, Mr. S. took them to the Bay. Susan received a letter from her sister Mary with news about Miss Hawley and Julia's whereabouts.

entries.fullText:
Rev Anna H. Shaw lecture
at Chautauqua assembly
[P.E.Club ????
?? ??? to Bessie Laughton
of Point Havens of
Leavenworth ???]
At Summerland
the morning bright warm
still & lovely- wrote
letter to sister Mary - sorry
to Mary S. Hay on death
of her father Crawfordsville
Ind.
entries.summaryText: Attended a lecture by Rev Anna H. Shaw at Chautauqua assembly. Also wrote a letter to sister Mary and expressed condolences to Mary S. Hay on the death of her father in Crawfordsville, Ind.

entries.fullText:
May Wright-Sewell to
be at Chautauqua this day.
entries.summaryText: May Wright-Sewell is scheduled to be at Chautauqua today.

entries.fullText: Historical Society meeting in Grand Father Anthonys door yard South Adams & all invited to be there - fifteen of us slept in the old house this night - on beds - cots & sofa - The rain stopped & a good audience gathered in Plunketts Pavillion in Forest Park - Adams - [?] 6 or 800 - a good lunch & good speeches by my girls - Upton, Foster Avery, Wright Sewell Colby, Blackwell, Chapman Catt -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a Historical Society meeting and sleeps in her grandfather's old house. She also gives speeches at an event in Forest Park.

entries.fullText: The family reunion today - some 80 sat down to tables spread in keeping room - grand fathers room & living room & nice talks from several after dinner -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a family reunion and listens to nice talks after dinner.

entries.fullText: Went to Greylock Summit at 6 white horse wagon with 17 - & a 4-bay horse wagon with 11 - in all 28 of us - then cousin William took brother Merritt in his buggy - making 30 of our party - But only Mrs. Sewall & Mrs. Colby were left -
entries.summaryText: Went to Greylock Summit with a group of 30 people, but only two were left at the end of the day.

entries.fullText: All the cousins took dinner at Aunt Maria's - & I could but feel how Uncle Humphrey would have enjoyed it to see us all there.
entries.summaryText: Had dinner with cousins at Aunt Maria's and thought about how Uncle Humphrey would have enjoyed it.

entries.fullText:
up at 5 & off for
North Adams - to take
7 A.M. train for Greenwich-
Mrs Sewall with us-
brothers Daniel & Merritt - sister
Mary & self- to visit
Battenville & Center Falls-

Left Albany at 8.10-
& reached Rochester at
2 P.M. - to find no
Julia- so that sister-
ill as she was had to
start in to get dinner
from the foundation-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to North Adams, Greenwich, Battenville, and Center Falls with Mrs. Sewall, brothers Daniel and Merritt, and sister Mary.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Brother Daniel left on the
10.27 train to regular - home
went to station with him - ,
I followed - a got mile down
Dhul bar -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home and her brother Daniel left on a train to go home. She went to the station with him and followed for a mile down Dhul bar.

entries.fullText:
Frances M. Clark came
& began house work
entries.summaryText: Frances M. Clark came and began house work.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Sewall went to
Church with us to see
& hear our old Pastor
Rev N. M. Mann -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Sewall went to church with us to see and hear our old Pastor Rev N. M. Mann.

entries.fullText:
AT home
We had to tea - Mrs
Sewall - Rev & Mrs Mann -
Mrs Hallowell (Mrs ? ill)
Mrs Blackall & Mrs Walters - Mrs
[?] Smith - Mrs Angle

an in evening, some hundred
called - Mr & Mrs Charles
Fitch among them -
and quite late
Cousin Hannah [Doyles ?] &
Melissa Dickinson arrived
entries.summaryText: Had tea with Mrs. Sewall, Rev & Mrs Mann, Mrs Hallowell, Mrs Blackall, Mrs Walters, Mrs Smith, Mrs Angle, Mr & Mrs Charles Fitch among others. Later, Cousin Hannah [Doyles ?] & Melissa Dickinson arrived while some hundred called in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Sewall left at
10 - A.M- and our
Cousins were moved
into the front chamber
entries.summaryText: Mrs Sewall left and Cousins moved into front chamber.

entries.fullText:
The Cousins spent
this day at Macedon
visiting the children
of Cousin John -
Macedon John's father
used to call him -
entries.summaryText: Cousins visited children of Cousin John in Macedon.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on August 12th, 1897.

entries.fullText: The cousins went to Avon & spent night - Merritt, Mary & self took tea at Mary Hallowells - with Mr Mann & others - When we reached home at 9.30 - [?] Mary Mills was here - so we made bed on Sofa bed in my study - & left the cousins bed ready for them [?] [nite ?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent August 13th, 1897 with her cousins in Avon and had tea with Merritt, Mary, Mary Hallowell, Mr. Mann, and others. Later, Mary Mills arrived at her home and they made a bed for her on the sofa bed in her study.

entries.fullText:
Was down town
with Merritt -
The cousins took
lunch at Sibleys &
stopped till 2 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was down town with Merritt. The cousins took lunch at Sibleys and stopped till 2 P.M.

entries.fullText:
Cousin Hannahs
Margaret Bouyles Davies &
husband
Barnes of Buffalo -
came & spent entire
day returning on the 9.50
P.M. train -
entries.summaryText: Cousin Hannahs, Margaret Bouyles Davies, and her husband Barnes of Buffalo came and spent the entire day, returning on the 9.50 P.M. train.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry written on August 16, 1897

entries.fullText:
The cousins Melissa
took the 6.20 P.M. train
for Chicago - which
lands them at 9 -
Wednesday A.M -
So now we are left with
brother Merritt
alone - wo is to
stay until after the
G.A.A. at Buffalo
a week [?]
entries.summaryText: Melissa took a train to Chicago and Merritt stayed behind until the G.A.A. at Buffalo.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a journal entry on August 20, 1897, stating that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
Received receipt for
$800 from H.[?].U. - with
letter - saying Mrs Catt, self
must agree about it ?!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a journal entry on August 21, 1897, stating that she received a receipt for $800 from H.[?].U. with a letter mentioning Mrs Catt and herself needing to agree about it.

entries.fullText:
Went to Chapel
to hear George Smith
tell of their Sundays
abroad - very prettily
done -
entries.summaryText: Attended Chapel to hear George Smith speak about Sundays abroad.

entries.fullText:
Brother Merritt
went to Buffalo to see
the Old Soldiers
arrive
Had next
to no callers this
evening - Oh yes Mr
Chapin of Fort Scott called
on way to Livonia
entries.summaryText: Brother Merritt went to Buffalo to see the Old Soldiers arrive. Mr. Chapin of Fort Scott called on his way to Livonia.

entries.fullText:
Brother MerritT
In Buffalo - came
at 9.20 - tired out -
in [bed ?] wit indigestion
- & I didn't get settled
until near midnight
entries.summaryText: Brother MerritT arrived in Buffalo and Susan had trouble settling in due to indigestion.

entries.fullText:
Brother decided he
didn't want to go back
to Buffalo today - so I
gae up seeing the
Grand March of the
Grand Army of the Republic
- and we settled down
to visiting - Our Rev
Anna Shaw came
in about 11. A.M -
from Alcott - where she
had spoken [?] P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan's brother decided not to go back to Buffalo, so they visited instead. Rev Anna Shaw also came to visit from Alcott.

entries.fullText:
Brother Merritt left at
9.50 A.M - went station with
him - expressed himself as
going home feeling in much
better heart in both mind & body -
- He has a good rest - with
three square meals a day for
a whole month -, he has
seemed to enjoy it - though
no words to say so -
Miss Shaw, sister Mary & self
went to tea at the Sanfords
to Mrs Anna Desant of
London - & then to Y.M.C.A.
Hall - where I presented Mrs B.
to about 200 people - Miss S.
sat in audience - & at
close - took train for
Ames - Iowa - Mrs Desant
is Master of best of English
& knows how to use it
to best advantage - I think
all were delighted with here -
though like myself - not accepting
her themes of his soul -
entries.summaryText: Brother Merritt left and Miss Shaw, sister Mary and Susan B. Anthony went to tea at the Sanfords to meet Mrs Anna Desant of London. Later, Susan presented Mrs B. to about 200 people at Y.M.C.A. Hall.

entries.fullText:
We had Mrs Desant
Mrs Sanford - Madeline, Mrs
[M D. Morse ?], Gertrude Blackall,
Mrs Dr Sozier of [?],
Mrs [No... ?] Miss Nilson,

to dinner - with no meat [prev. 2 words underlined] - a
very pleasant time - then
at 8 - a smaller audience
not over 200 greeted Mrs
Desant - & she gave
the practical duties of
[...sophists ?] for to day
most excellent - she
impresses me with her
learning & knowledge
on all lines -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had Mrs Desant, Mrs Sanford, Madeline, Mrs [M D. Morse ?], Gertrude Blackall, Mrs Dr Sozier of [?], Mrs [No... ?], and Miss Nilson over for dinner. Later, Mrs Desant gave a speech to a smaller audience.

entries.fullText:
Called at Mrs Sanfords
to say a good by to Mrs
Besant & Countess [Meitch ?]
Meister - It is evident that
Mrs Sanford will be the Pres
of the new Theosophist
Society that is to represent
Mrs Besant [?] -

Then we dined with
Mrs Morse - ev. B. - to meet
her brother's wife - Mrs Pase
of St Louis Mo - & their son
Williams wife & step mother
Mrs Fletcher - a very good
time - came home early -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Mrs. Sanford, Mrs. Besant, and Countess Meitch Meister. She then dines with Mrs. Morse, Mrs. Pase, Williams, and Mrs. Fletcher.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self went
to Unitarian Chapel to hear
Mrs Dr. [Dendorn ?] [?]
on Theosophy - a nice
number of women & a few
men present - Mr Gannett
there - Mrs. D. did very nicely
indeed -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister attend a talk on Theosophy given by Mrs. Dr. [Dendorn ?]. Mr. Gannett is also present.

entries.fullText:
At home
Miss Gertrude Blackall
came at 8 A.M. & took
dictation for several letters -
Miss Rathburn
of Aurora - N.Y. came
to try her hand as my
stenographer & helped -
she seems a quiet & bright
person -
At our " at home" - this
evening Miss Imogene Dewey
brought two ladies from
Canada - & two from
Norwalk Ohio - & Miss [Rischen ?]
back & the Misses Mabbett came
Mrs Mary Stocking Knaggs &
husband - of Bay City, Michigan -
came to tea - spent evening - & took
10.10 train for Detroit. -
& at 10 - Mrs Blackall with Mrs
Fred Douglas of Washington D.C. - and
Miss Gertruide & Mr Gold - who is going
to Cincinnati to study for a [Rabbi ?] - [?]
entries.summaryText: Miss Gertrude Blackall and Miss Rathburn helped with dictation. Guests from Canada, Norwalk Ohio, and Bay City, Michigan visited. Mrs. Fred Douglas of Washington D.C. also visited.

entries.fullText:
Dictated until 12 -
then dressed - & sister Mary
& self went to dinner in
honor of Mrs Douglas - at
Mrs Blackalls shehad a
large round table with 14
seated - Mr Garmett brought
Rev Fred Hosmer , Mrs
Lucy B. Smith brought a
niece from St Louis - so I
talked with each of Mrs [?]
of that city - & both aid
none of best people would or
could join with her -
Charlotte [Milburn ?] [suffering ?] - Mrs [Walters ?] &
daughter Gertrude were there
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had dinner in honor of Mrs. Douglas. Guests from St. Louis were also present.

entries.fullText: At home - dictating letters - & looking over & sorting newspaper clippings & playing in years - A lovely rain in P.M. & evening - Sister Mary Pasting slips in 1874 Scrap book - Mrs Stanton wrote one to go instanter to Geneva - but must stick to work here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home, sorting newspaper clippings and playing. Sister Mary pastes slips in a scrapbook and Mrs. Stanton writes a letter to Geneva.

entries.fullText: At home - Dictating letters to my little new secretary - Miss Rackham of Aurora -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dictates letters to her new secretary, Miss Rackham of Aurora, at home.

entries.fullText:
Rev. B. G. Roger
Pres. of [Bengonia?] College
at [Bengonia ?0 Mich -
who lived at Ogdensburg N.Y
1894 - & Miss Shaw, Miss Hannah [?]
May & self stopped with them -
his wife a very bright woman -
Left home on 5.10 train
for Geneva - Found no
carriage at Station - so
had to pay $1. to go out -
& on arrival found
they had read my Postal
card 8.10 - instead of
5.10 - but since there was
no 8.10 leaving R. it was to
say the least funny that they
could guess it meant 5 -
even if the figure was
very [?] -which it was
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her trip to Geneva, mentioning the people she stayed with and the confusion over her train time.

entries.fullText:
Geneva N.Y.
at
Mrs Eliz. Smith Miller's
Mrs Stanton same as ever
Spent day talking
about 50th anniversary
celebration but
her hobby - craze -
now is Educated
Suffrage - as if
all [underlined] were included
in that one qualification
I do hope she will
get out of it into a view
of the whole great
half century's work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day with Mrs. Eliz. Smith Miller and Mrs. Stanton, discussing the 50th anniversary celebration and Mrs. Stanton's focus on educated suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Wea. SUN. SEPT. 5, 1897 Ther.
[handwritten after Wea. is the word "hot"]

Geneva - N.Y.
Eliz. Smiths Miller's
to visit with Mrs Stanton
At 10 A.M. the
Coachman - John - took
me to see Aunt Amy
Read Hane's youngest
