son - Lucious Howe - &
his two daughters -
Nina - & Henrietta - Ella
the first an invalid for years -
the latter does all the work
for the three - Cousin [?]
in very helpless state -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Geneva, NY and spends time with family members including Aunt Amy, Lucious Howe, Nina, Henrietta, and Cousin.

entries.fullText:
Wea. MON. SEPT. 6, 1897 Ther.
[handwritten above Wea. are the words "very hot day"

Left Geneva at 12.05
- Mrs Stanton, Maggie &
Dudley Millers widow
went to Station with me -
I called again at
Cousin Lucious - I
wish I could do
for them - cousin Marietta's daughters
husband - Mr Nestor -
has been for years very
kind but they feel he
is withdrawing [underlined] his help -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Geneva, NY and mentions visiting Cousin Lucious and the withdrawal of help from Mr. Nestor for Marietta's daughters.

entries.fullText:
a little cooler

at home -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about being at home on a cooler day.

entries.fullText:
Churchville - 3 P.M.
Mrs Martha J. Hattly Stebbins
Martha J. Hattly Stebbins
- Took 10.55 train - diner
with Mrs Stebbins - she had
Mrs Graves, Mrs Smith
& Mrs ___ then [?]
spoke in Baptist Church
some 200 women from
miles around - a dozzen
men or so - Mrs Parish
introduced me - Mrs
Stebbins paid me $10 out of her
own pocket
Before leaving home
in A.M. dictated 4 letters
to Gertrude Blackall - & 4 to
my little girl Amy A. Rathburn -
& after return at 6 - supped &
read over the 8 letters, signed, sealed
stamped & mailed them -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about speaking at the Baptist Church in Churchville, where she was introduced by Mrs. Parish and paid $10 by Mrs. Stebbins. She also dictated and mailed several letters before and after the event.

entries.fullText: At home worked on papers & clippings in the attic all day. This P.M. papers tell of a horrid murder at Churchville early this A.M - Smith the name - the craze of husbands to get possession of their wives money seems to be the initiating course in this as in the Benham's & other cases.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about working on papers and clippings at home. She also mentions a murder that occurred in Churchville and the trend of husbands trying to get their wives' money.

entries.fullText: At home worked on clippings all day - & then after supper walked to Mrs. Hallowells - spent an hour or more there walked back home.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about working on clippings at home and visiting Mrs. Hallowell in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Went to Dentist
Requa - first thing
after breakfast - to
get plate fixed -
then all day again
in the attic -
entries.summaryText: Went to the dentist and spent the day in the attic.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self went to
Church - Mr G's subject today -
to use whatever talent we
possess to best of ability -
entries.summaryText: Went to church with Sister Mary and heard Mr. G's sermon about using our talents to the best of our ability.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry written on September 13, 1897

entries.fullText: Lette from Mr. [?] W. Bradley - Sup't of Bradstreet Co - Phila - Penn - Lock Box 1557 - Phila - P.O. asking sundry questions as to nephew Burts capacities to work for them - which I answered as best I could and wrote the man I hope he would give the young man a trial - & so see for themselves what he was good for -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from Mr. [?] W. Bradley, the Sup't of Bradstreet Co in Phila - Penn, asking about her nephew Burt's capacities to work for them. She answered the letter and hoped that they would give him a trial to see what he was good for.

entries.fullText:
A Postal card from nephew
Burt this A.M. dated Sept. 14/97
Am taking my noon hour &
thought to write you this card to tell
you that everything goes lovely. Got
a raise in salary after the first
days which will make me
independent - your truly, Burt
This looks good & if the boy
only holds out he'll be all right
he is with the Bradstreet & Co.
Philadelphia, Penn
entries.summaryText: Burt sent a postcard to Susan B. Anthony from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, informing her that he got a raise in salary and everything is going well.

entries.fullText: Dentist [Regua ?] - at 8.30 [time is underlined]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a dentist appointment with someone named Regua at 8:30.

entries.fullText:
Ohio annual State W.S.A
Con. Alliance - after writing
"no" - H.J. Upton telegraphed - Holding
Alliance Convention depends on
you. For Heavens sake come
October 7th - wire answer - H.J.U.
this came Sept 11. & I wired "yes"
thought I ought to have stuck to "no"
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a telegram from H.J. Upton inviting her to the Ohio annual State W.S.A Con. Alliance Convention and she agrees to attend.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester - 9.05 A.M.
reached Syracuse - 11.15 -
Harriet Mary Mills met me -
p found Mr C.J.D. Mills feeble -
- at [9?]. P.M. found the
May Church well filled -
- good speaking -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Rochester to Syracuse, meets with Harriet Mary Mills and Mr C.J.D. Mills, attends a well-attended speaking event at May Church.

entries.fullText: [no entry for this date]

entries.fullText:
At Nashivlle - Tenn -
All hands drove out
to the Hermitage [two words underlined] - The
old homestead of Andrew Jackson
- Lucy E. & self excepted -
- I went to Fisk University
Chapel - at 10.20 - heard a
colored man preach - &
promised to go out & talk to
the 600 students Monday A.M.,
- at 3 P.M. spoke at
the Liberal Religious meeting
in Jewish synagogue - Rev
Dr Thomas Pres - Jenkin
Lloyd Hones, Sec'y -
at evening went to Gospel
Tabernackle - Sam Jones -
to hear Rev Anna Shaw preach -
- went home to supper with
a Jewish lady - Mrs -
& from there to the Tabernacles
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits The Hermitage, Fisk University Chapel, a Jewish synagogue, and Gospel Tabernackle in Nashville, Tennessee. She hears a colored man preach, speaks at a Liberal Religious meeting, and hears Rev Anna Shaw preach at the Gospel Tabernackle. She also has supper with a Jewish lady.

entries.fullText:
- at 8.18 - drove out to
Fisk University with the
President - spoke to the
students of the Old Abolitionists
& women's rights there & [?]
for an hour - then was
driven over to the Exposition
grounds by the Treasurer
- found all beautiful - but
the Assembly room damp & dull
[?] so with
entries.summaryText: Spoke at Fisk University and visited the Exposition grounds.

Carson City --

Minneapolis - Minn -

entries.fullText:
3rd National Conference
Chicago, IL
entries.summaryText: Attended 3rd National Conference in Chicago, IL.

entries.fullText: Arrive at 6:15 - Mr & Mrs Delos Blodgett met us with carriage - & too S.B. to their house - lovely - Miss Shaw to arrive tomorrow A.M. she speaks to night at Hammond Inst - Mrs C.C.C. & Miss Hay were put by Mrs Harvey Hollister & taken to her beautiful house - Twice I was in G.R. Mr Blodgett has a young wife & has little ones - a girl 2 yrs & a boy 1 year
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Grand Rapids, Michigan and is greeted by Mr. and Mrs. Delos Blodgett. Miss Shaw is expected to arrive the next day and speak at Hammond Institute. Mrs. C.C.C. and Miss Hay are taken to Mrs. Harvey Hollister's house. Mr. Blodgett has a young wife and two children.
Second day of the 4th National Conference in Grand Rapids, Michigan.

entries.fullText:
Kalamazoo - Mich -
Shaw & Anthony
Rev Caroline J. Bartlett
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated November 24, 1897 from Kalamazoo, Michigan mentioning Shaw, Anthony, and Rev Caroline J. Bartlett.

entries.cityOrState:
left Kalamazoo at 7 A.M.
reached Toledo - Ohio
at 2 P.M. & went
to Claudia Quigley Murphy's
- friend there Mrs Catt &
Miss Hay - - Spent
night here with all
the rest - Miss Shaw &
self slept together - but
not much sleep for me.
entries.fullText:
Thanksgiving Day -
William McKinley - Pres
William Black Gov. of New York
left Kalamazoo at 7 A.M.
reached Toledo - Ohio
at 2 P.M. & went
to Claudia Quigley Murphy's
- friend there Mrs Catt &
Miss Hay - - Spent
night here with all
the rest - Miss Shaw &
self slept together - but
not much sleep for me.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated November 25, 1897 mentioning Thanksgiving Day, William McKinley, William Black, Claudia Quigley Murphy, Mrs Catt, Miss Hay, and Miss Shaw. The entry also mentions traveling from Kalamazoo to Toledo and spending the night at Claudia Quigley Murphy's.

entries.fullText: Miss Shaw left for Youngstown to speak this ev'g & I went to Mrs Randolphs [nice?] [people?] very made my speech this evening
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw left for Youngstown and Susan B. Anthony made a speech in Toledo, Ohio.

entries.fullText: Miss Shaw arrived at noon - at Mrs Randolph's & made her main speech this evening At 11 P.M. I took train for home Miss Hay & Mrs. Catt on same train - Miss Shaw to leave for Wisconsin tomorrow A.M. - I never heard [some?] rolicking & [fury?] there this evening
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw made a speech in Toledo, Ohio and Susan B. Anthony left for home with Miss Hay and Mrs. Catt on the same train while Miss Shaw was leaving for Wisconsin the next day.

entries.fullText:
Reached home at
10 - A.M. - & found
all well -- Mrs Harper
feeling I had put
back the biography
work fearfully - well
it has been a rest
to me anyway
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived home and found Mrs. Harper feeling well. She reflects on putting back the biography work and feeling rested.

entries.fullText:
At Home
and pitching into
scrap book work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and working on her scrapbook.

entries.fullText: Dear Mother's 104th Birth Day
entries.summaryText: Celebrating Mother's 104th Birthday

entries.fullText: Finished clippings for scrap-book for 1893 At 6 P.M. Sister Mary, Mrs. Harper, Amy Rachturn & myself - went to U. Church Parlor to Annual Christmas Sale & supper -a big crowd & $400 net
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony finished clippings for scrap-book and attended the Annual Christmas Sale and supper with Sister Mary, Mrs. Harper, and Amy Rachturn, where they raised $400.

entries.fullText: At home Marking upon clippings of 1894 - The New York Con. Con. and the Kansas Suffrage Council Mont campaigns - & fearfuly big 20th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home marking clippings of 1894 related to the New York Constitutional Convention, the Kansas Suffrage Council, and the Montana campaigns.

entries.fullText: Went to hear Mr. Gannet - his text from Mr. Moody "Character is what a man is in the dark" - It was a good talk. Sister Mary bro't letters from Miss Lucy E - & H.T. Upton - the latter with a check of $50 - for my clerk hire to [?] & [?] for 1897 - The Women of California sent 85 for Poor Women - tomorrow I will put all Press contributions into Trust Bank where Emma B Sweet is custodian. they are now - Sam'l [Nicholson?] 10 - Susan J Chase 10 - Cornelia C. Hasry 50 - [H???] 5 - total - 75 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about hearing a good talk by Mr. Gannet, receiving letters and a check from Miss Lucy E and H.T. Upton, and receiving a donation from the Women of California for poor women. She also mentions putting press contributions into the Trust Bank.
Susan B. Anthony writes that she is at home.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home on December 16, 1897.

entries.fullText: All hands took supper at Unitarian Parlors - at the Church sale & Supper - My only outing since return from Conferences -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she went to the Unitarian Parlors and Church sale and supper, which was her only outing since returning from Conferences, on December 17, 1897.

entries.fullText:
Sent N.Y. Life Ins Co
$34.70 - for 1898 premium
-In just 40 years have I paid
premiums on my 2,000 Life Policy
- Mrs. Harper is finishing
1892 - with the Worlds Fair in
Chicago - Amy Rathburn
is pasting Kansas campaign&
1894 - in scrap book -
Mrs Hawley copying chap.
of the biography -
Little Miss Meilke copy -
Omaha speech - Mormon [?]
had met her Ballot of 1882 -
& myself - sorting & hiring
together the clippings of
1895
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about paying her life insurance premium and mentions various people and locations she has been sorting through clippings with.

entries.fullText: This is sister Guelma's Aaron's 85 birthday all of us at home - Sister Mary, Mrs Harper, Miss Amy Rathburn & self & at work-also Miss Hawley and Miss Meilke - type-writing so we closed the year hard at work & I can say it has been one of as steady grind as any I ever had among it has been over papers & speech - reading & writing &c
entries.summaryText: Celebrating Guelma's Aaron's 85th birthday with family and colleagues, and reflecting on a year of hard work including reading, writing, and speeches.

In trust for cause from
Dr Cordelia Green 500.
Since May 1895

entries.fullText: An unprecedented pessenger[sic] train service is offered by the NEW YORK CENTRAL. entries.fullText:
The Equipment of the
"NORTH SHORE LIMITED"
is as follows:

Combination Baggage, Buffet, Library
and Smoking Car, between New York
and Chicago.

Private Compartment Sleeping Car
between New York and Chicago.

Ten-section and double State-Room
Sleeping Car, between New York and
Chicago.

Buffet Sleeping Car, Chicago to Boston.
Sleeping Car, Detroit to New York

Drawing-Room Car, New York to
Niagara Falls, Westbound, and Syracuse
to New York Eastbound.

Dining-Car, New York to Buffalo and
Niles to Chicago, Westbound. Chicago
to Detroit and Utica to New York, Eastbound.

NOTE.--Passengers on westbound train from
New York for Chicago or points west thereof, are
required to have in addition to full first-class passage
ticket, an excess fare and sleeping care ticket.
Passes not honored. Special tickets and Sleeping
Car tickets are required on eastbound train, from
Chicago, Detroit and intermediate stations to New
York City. Passes not honored.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the equipment of the North Shore Limited train, including the types of cars and sleeping arrangements available, as well as information about ticketing and passes.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Nancy Howe Clark, mother of Mrs.
Emily Clark Griggs, died at the home of
her daughter, Mrs. A. Orming Griggs, at
Westford, Otsego county, on the 11th instant,
aged 85 years and 10 months. Mrs.
Clark's mother, Amy Read Howe, was
the elder and only sister of Susan B. and
Mary S. Anthony's mother, Lucy Read Anthony.
In her girlhood days when Susan
B. Anthony was 12 years old, Nancy Howe
was the teacher of the family school where
she attended.
